 **From my recollection of "Chaos" by Gleick he gave an example along the lines of...
 
 A scientist in Australia wants to describe the behaviour of a newly discovered living micro-organism called 'x'. He uses a microscope to study it. He describes it. He publishes his findings in a paper. A lab in Germany, another in the USA, one in Japan, and one in Scotland all get samples of living 'x' and each lab follows a scientific method in observing 'x' under the microscope. Their reports match the initial report. It is published because peer review has checked the facts and 'x' is said to be a certain way. It enters the realm of scientific 'fact'.
 HOWEVER, Gleick goes on to say, that 'x' is observed by a microscope using a source of light to illuminate it. Unknown to the scientists is that 'x' is light sensitive. In order to perform an observation, the scientist influences the observation. Each lab is using similar lights/microscopes and thus affecting their observations in the same way. You can not, according to Gleick, know how 'x' really behaves; or more to the point, repeated observations are only of a limited value as explanation of how 'x' behaves. He then returns to the old puzzle, if a tree falls in a forest and no one is there, does it make a sound? To which he answers "You can't know".
